The Toxic Exposures Fund was created to guarantee veterans get the care they need by classifying future investments in this fund as mandatory.

This would prevent politicians from playing political games with this vital support ‚Äî like Republicans are doing now.

CBO estimates that, over time, future discretionary spending for veterans‚Äô medical care will instead be funded as mandatory from this account.

The PACT Act does not specify those amounts. Congress will separately determine other discretionary spending for veterans‚Äô medical care.

Don‚Äôt be fooled by their misleading excuses. Here are the facts:

It does NOT retroactively ‚Äúconvert‚Äù previously appropriated amounts.

It does NOT include any spending unrelated to veterans.
The GOP opposes this plan but since they can‚Äôt stop it they are blocking the PACT Act. This shameful display of political pouting has real and dangerous consequences for sick veterans.

So what DID change?

Right before Republicans turned their back on toxic-exposed vets, Democrats announced a plan to reduce inflation, act on climate, and lower prescription drug prices.

Senate Republicans claim they now oppose the bill because of a reclassification of funds ‚Äî but there's one major flaw in their excuse:

Those same Republicans already voted for the same language.

Not a single word of the Toxic Exposures Fund changed since that June 16th vote.
